item.title: Remove!#$%^!
item.dc:creator: @tigerclan tigerclan
item.description:
@tigerclan wrote:

Everyone has already giving you tons of different advice on how to internally manipulate and store variables with php and javascript. You can’t expect us to go out of our way and just write your code for you, or go and search the internet for code that will work for exactly what you want, when you aren’t even willing to try and learn yourself.

Read full topic

item.title: Remove!#$%^!
item.dc:creator: @Saige Saige
item.description:
@Saige wrote:

I really have no idea how to do this for the past day i’ve being searching for one that doesn’t refresh on page refresh but I can’t seem to find one I was asking if anyone knows of a simple ready made one or a tutorial for one.

Read full topic

item.title: Remove!#$%^!
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“Saige, post:3, topic:527067”]Would I just add this code in and it will work?

[code=javascript]// Get the text field that we’re going to track
var field = document.getElementById(“field”);

// See if we have an autosave value
// (this will only happen if the page is accidentally refreshed)
if ( sessionStorage.getItem(“autosave”)) {
// Restore the contents of the text field
field.value = sessionStorage.getItem(“autosave”);
}

// Check the contents of the text field every second
setInterval(function(){
// And save the results into the session storage object
sessionStorage.setItem(“autosave”, field.value);
}, 1000);[/code][/quote]

Why don’t you just try it for yourself? You seem to have no independence.

Read full topic

item.title: Remove!#$%^!
item.dc:creator: @Saige Saige
item.description:
@Saige wrote:

Would I just add this code in and it will work?

[code=javascript]// Get the text field that we’re going to track
var field = document.getElementById(“field”);

// See if we have an autosave value
// (this will only happen if the page is accidentally refreshed)
if ( sessionStorage.getItem(“autosave”)) {
// Restore the contents of the text field
field.value = sessionStorage.getItem(“autosave”);
}

// Check the contents of the text field every second
setInterval(function(){
// And save the results into the session storage object
sessionStorage.setItem(“autosave”, field.value);
}, 1000);[/code]

Read full topic

item.title: Remove!#$%^!
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Don’t pass strings into setTimeout or setInterval.

You can use localStorage to store where the counter’s at. Figure out how to implement it yourself, it isn’t very hard.

MDN Web Docs

Web Storage API

The Web Storage API provides mechanisms by which browsers can store key/value pairs, in a much more intuitive fashion than using cookies.

Read full topic
